title: Folio 3H/I
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">This part of the composition shows Anthony’s encounter with ancient Greek deities on Mount Olympus. In Ensor’s treatment of the meeting, however, the classical temple described by Gustave Flaubert in his Temptation of Saint Anthony looks more like the Brussels opera house, the Royal Theater of the Mint (Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie, or La Monnaie), which was rebuilt in 1856 in a Neoclassical style after designs by Joseph Poelaert (see fig. 1). A bas-relief by Eugène Simonis, Harmony of Human Passions (1854), fills the pediment of the actual building; here it has been replaced by the letter M, a possible reference to the theater’s name. The gods Zeus, Hera, Heracles, and Hermes (in Roman mythology, Jupiter, Juno, Hercules, and Mercury, respectively) are assembled along the pediment roof. Other features—the grandiose scale and the scene’s juxtaposition with a nearby maritime view—are suggestive of the scenery that Ensor might have seen in the Royal Theater’s performances. For example, he attended a performance of Wagner’s Die Walküre (The Valkyrie) there on March 9, 1887. In the center of the folio, a bare-breasted man holding a spear and shield and wearing a tall, mitered hat topped by a feather bears a resemblance to an African tribal chief or perhaps one of the Babylonian gods mentioned by Flaubert. The staff the figure holds was reworked in the sheet below (4I) in response to a shift in alignment caused by the mounting process (see fig. 2). Beside him are three six-pointed stars, a possible allusion to Freemasonry. The bared buttocks and defecation to the right of the figure add a note of scatological mockery to the otherwise sober scene.

The folio was drawn in concert with neighboring sheets 4H and 4I before they were mounted to the canvas. Initially they may have been attached to another surface while they were worked out as a group. SMC/KJN

Ensor’s fascination with the visual energy produced by the contrasts of light and dark and the interaction of his figures within pictorial space is reflected in both this sheet and the print Capture of a Strange Town (fig. 3; see also sheets 3F, 3G, 4F, 4G, 4H, and 4I). Indeed, the artist was constantly preoccupied by light and space. Ensor had a strong memory for composition and design; the work of other artists seems to have frequently stuck with him and been integrated into his own oeuvre. Closer consideration of Capture of a Strange Town reveals a probable source for its composition: the mezzotint Belshazzar’s Feast by John Martin, an English Romantic artist and favorite of King Leopold I of Belgium (fig. 4). The explosion of the elements and fantastical landscapes lie at the heart of Martin’s biblical scenes, which exhibit an energy that clearly left its mark on Ensor. The Belgian artist likely saw Martin’s work in Ernest Chesneau’s La peinture anglaise (English Painting; A. Quantin, 1882), as he copied several works from this book. ST

fig. 1 The facade of the Royal Theater of the Mint, c. 1880.

fig. 2 Digital manipulation of folio 3H/I and sheets 4H and 4I of Ensor’s Temptation of Saint Anthony (1887–88) showing the original image alignment prior to mounting (1) and the positions of the sheets as actually mounted (2). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006.87.

fig. 3 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Capture of a Strange Town, 1888. Etching on paper; image: 17.2 × 23.2 cm (6 3/4 × 9 1/8 in.); plate: 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 35.6 × 47.9 cm (14 × 18 7/8 in.). The Museum of Modern Art, New York, Purchase, 115.1949. Digital image © The Museum of Modern Art/Licensed by SCALA/Art Resource, NY.

fig. 4 John Martin (English, 1789-1854). Belshazzar’s Feast from Illustrations of the Bible, 1835. Mezzotint in black on ivory wove paper; image: 19 × 29 cm (7 1/2 × 11 7/16 in.); plate: 26.8 × 35.7 cm (10 9/16 × 14 1/16 in.); sheet: 32.9 × 41.6 cm (12 15/16 × 16 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Mary S. Adams Endowment, 1991.216.7.
